title: Revelation Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Revelation chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Revelation Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Revelation Chapter 9.

questions.question: Who was given the key of the bottomless pit?
options: A star that fell from heaven
questions.correctAnswer: A star that fell from heaven
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:1 states that a star fell from heaven to the earth, and to him was given the key of the bottomless pit.

questions.question: What darkened the sun and the air according to Revelation 9?
questions.correctAnswer: Smoke from the bottomless pit
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:2 says that smoke arose from the bottomless pit, darkening the sun and the air.

questions.question: What creatures came out of the smoke from the bottomless pit?
questions.correctAnswer: Locusts
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:3 describes locusts coming out of the smoke from the bottomless pit.

questions.question: Who were the locusts commanded not to hurt?
options: The grass, green things, and trees
The men with the seal of God
questions.correctAnswer: The grass, green things, and trees
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:4 states the locusts were commanded not to hurt the grass, green things, or trees, but only men without the seal of God.

questions.question: For how long were the locusts allowed to torment men?
questions.correctAnswer: Five months
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:5 says the locusts were given power to torment men for five months.

questions.question: What did men seek during the torment of the locusts but could not find?
questions.correctAnswer: Death
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:6 states men sought death but could not find it during the torment.

questions.question: What were the locusts' faces like?
questions.correctAnswer: Faces of men
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:7 describes the locusts as having faces like men.

questions.question: What were the tails of the locusts like?
questions.correctAnswer: Like scorpions with stings
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:10 states the locusts had tails like scorpions with stings.

questions.question: What is the Hebrew name of the king over the locusts?
questions.correctAnswer: Abaddon
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:11 identifies the king of the locusts as Abaddon in Hebrew.

questions.question: How many woes are mentioned in Revelation 9?
questions.correctAnswer: Three
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:12 mentions that one woe has passed and two more woes are coming, totaling three woes.

questions.question: True or False: The four angels were bound at the great river Tigris.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:14 says the four angels were bound at the great river Euphrates, not Tigris.

questions.question: True or False: The four angels were released to kill a third part of mankind.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:15 states the four angels were loosed to kill a third part of men.

questions.question: True or False: The horses' heads were like the heads of serpents.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:17 describes the horses' heads as like lions, not serpents.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Revelation 9:20: 'And the rest of the men which were not killed by these plagues yet repented not of the works of their hands, that they should not worship ________.'
options: devils, and idols of gold, and silver, and brass
questions.correctAnswer: devils, and idols of gold, and silver, and brass
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:20 says men did not repent to stop worshiping devils and idols of gold, silver, and brass.

questions.question: What did the horses and riders have on their breastplates in the vision?
questions.correctAnswer: Fire, jacinth, and brimstone
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:17 describes the riders having breastplates of fire, jacinth, and brimstone.

medium.title: Revelation Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Revelation Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear during trials. Based on Revelation 9:1-2, what biblical truth would you share about God's control in difficult times?
options: God allows challenges but holds the keys to release and restriction
God abandons believers when trials come
Trials come without any divine purpose
Believers will never face serious trials
questions.correctAnswer: God allows challenges but holds the keys to release and restriction
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:1-2 shows a star given the key to the bottomless pit, indicating God controls even the opening of severe trials. This teaches us that trials come under God's sovereign control and purpose.

questions.question: How does Revelation 9:3-5 teach about the importance of spiritual protection and perseverance during affliction?
options: Believers without God's seal may face spiritual attack but are preserved from destruction
Believers are immune to all trials
Afflictions always lead to immediate death
Physical destruction is the main concern for believers
questions.correctAnswer: Believers without God's seal may face spiritual attack but are preserved from destruction
questions.explanation: Verses 3-5 describe locusts tormenting men without God's seal but not killing them, teaching that God's protection preserves believers and calls for perseverance during spiritual trials.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by ongoing spiritual battles. What insight does Revelation 9:6 offer about enduring suffering and the hope beyond it?
options: People will seek death but it will not come, showing the intensity of trials
Suffering will be brief and easy
Trials are signs of God's rejection
questions.correctAnswer: People will seek death but it will not come, showing the intensity of trials
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:6 explains that during intense affliction, people desire death but cannot find it, encouraging believers to trust God's timing and purpose in suffering rather than despair.

questions.question: How does the imagery of locusts with crowns and human faces in Revelation 9:7 encourage believers in humility and vigilance?
options: Spiritual adversaries may appear powerful and cunning but God is sovereign
Pride is acceptable in spiritual warfare
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual adversaries may appear powerful and cunning but God is sovereign
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:7 describes locusts with crowns and human faces, symbolizing deceptive power, reminding believers to remain humble and vigilant relying on God's strength.

questions.question: Based on Revelation 9:9-10, what practical advice can be given about dealing with persistent temptations and trials?
options: Temptations can be painful and persistent, requiring steadfast faith and prayer
Temptations are always brief and easily overcome
Avoidance is the only defense against temptation
Physical armor is sufficient protection from trials
questions.correctAnswer: Temptations can be painful and persistent, requiring steadfast faith and prayer
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 depict locusts with scorpion tails causing pain over months, illustrating that trials can be prolonged and intense, encouraging believers to persevere in faith and prayer.

questions.question: What does Revelation 9:11 teach about recognizing spiritual authority and remaining faithful?
options: There are spiritual rulers opposing God, but believers must trust God's ultimate authority
Believers can control spiritual powers themselves
questions.correctAnswer: There are spiritual rulers opposing God, but believers must trust God's ultimate authority
questions.explanation: Verse 11 names the angel of the bottomless pit as Abaddon/Apollyon, showing there is evil authority, but believers are called to trust God's sovereign power over all spirits.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged that one trial has passed but more come. Based on Revelation 9:12, what encouragement can you offer about perseverance?
options: Even though one woe has passed, two more come, teaching endurance and hope in God's plan
Believers are exempt from multiple trials
questions.correctAnswer: Even though one woe has passed, two more come, teaching endurance and hope in God's plan
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:12 acknowledges ongoing woes, encouraging believers to endure faithfully and trust God's ultimate victory beyond the trials.

questions.question: How does Revelation 9:13-15 emphasize the importance of trusting God's timing and purpose in hardships?
options: Four angels are bound until a specific time, showing God controls the duration of trials
God has no control over hardships
Believers should rush to end trials themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Four angels are bound until a specific time, showing God controls the duration of trials
questions.explanation: Verses 13-15 describe angels bound until an appointed time, teaching believers to trust God's sovereign timing in all difficulties.

questions.question: What does the description of the 200 million horsemen in Revelation 9:16-17 teach about the seriousness of spiritual warfare and the need for vigilance?
options: The vast and terrifying army symbolizes intense spiritual battles requiring prayer and faith
Spiritual warfare is a minor issue
Physical weapons are the key to victory
questions.correctAnswer: The vast and terrifying army symbolizes intense spiritual battles requiring prayer and faith
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 describe a huge, fiery army representing serious spiritual conflict, reminding believers to be vigilant and dependent on God in prayer.

questions.question: A believer asks why some people do not repent despite severe judgments. Based on Revelation 9:20-21, what insight can you share about human response to God's discipline?
options: Many refuse to repent and continue sinful practices even after punishment
All people immediately repent after trials
Judgments always lead to universal repentance
Sinful habits are easily broken without God's help
questions.correctAnswer: Many refuse to repent and continue sinful practices even after punishment
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 reveal that despite plagues, many do not repent of idolatry, murders, or sins, highlighting the need for persistent evangelism and prayer.

questions.question: How does Revelation 9:19 teach about discerning and resisting evil influences in daily life?
options: Evil's power is in speech and actions, so believers must guard their hearts and tongues
Evil is harmless and can be ignored
Only physical strength can resist evil
Evil influences come only from outside sources
questions.correctAnswer: Evil's power is in speech and actions, so believers must guard their hearts and tongues
questions.explanation: Verse 19 shows the power of evil in mouths and tails (actions), teaching believers to practice self-control and resist temptation in speech and behavior.

questions.question: True or False: Revelation 9:4 teaches that God's people are protected from spiritual torment during trials.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 4 commands that the locusts should not harm those with God's seal on their foreheads, indicating divine protection for believers during trials.

questions.question: True or False: According to Revelation 9:5, the torment inflicted by the locusts lasts indefinitely without end.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 5 specifies the torment lasts five months, showing God limits the duration of suffering, which encourages endurance and hope.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Revelation 9:14 instructs the sixth angel to ______ the four angels bound at the great river Euphrates.
questions.correctAnswer: Loose
questions.explanation: Verse 14 commands the sixth angel to 'Loose' the four bound angels, illustrating God's control over the release of judgment.

questions.question: How does Revelation 9:18 encourage believers to rely on God amid suffering and loss?
options: A third of men are killed by fire, smoke, and brimstone, showing the reality of suffering but God's ultimate control
Believers can avoid all loss by their own efforts
God is powerless in times of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: A third of men are killed by fire, smoke, and brimstone, showing the reality of suffering but God's ultimate control
questions.explanation: Verse 18 reveals severe judgment but underscores the need to trust God’s sovereign plan through trials.

hard.title: Revelation Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Revelation Chapter 9.

questions.question: What key was given to the star that fell from heaven in Revelation 9:1, and what does it symbolize in the context of ancient Near Eastern beliefs?
options: The key of the bottomless pit, symbolizing authority over the realm of the dead
The key of the heavens, symbolizing divine judgment
The key of the temple, symbolizing access to God’s presence
The key of the scroll, symbolizing revelation of secrets
questions.correctAnswer: The key of the bottomless pit, symbolizing authority over the realm of the dead
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:1 states the star was given the key of the bottomless pit, representing authority over a deep, imprisoning place often linked to death and chaos in ancient symbolism.

questions.question: The smoke from the bottomless pit darkened the sun and air. Which Old Testament event is this imagery most closely connected to, reflecting divine judgment?
options: The plague of darkness in Egypt (Exodus 10)
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah (Genesis 19)
The pillar of cloud and fire leading Israel (Exodus 13)
questions.correctAnswer: The plague of darkness in Egypt (Exodus 10)
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:2 describes smoke darkening sun and air, paralleling Exodus 10 where darkness was a plague, symbolizing divine judgment and the withdrawal of God’s light.

questions.question: What power were the locusts given in Revelation 9:3, and what does this suggest about their nature in biblical symbolism?
options: Power like scorpions to torment men, symbolizing painful judgment
Power to devour crops, symbolizing famine
Power to bring death, symbolizing destruction
questions.correctAnswer: Power like scorpions to torment men, symbolizing painful judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states locusts had power as scorpions to torment, highlighting a judgment that afflicts without killing, consistent with symbolic torment in biblical literature.

questions.question: According to Revelation 9:4, who were the locusts commanded not to harm, and what theological significance does this group represent?
options: Those who have the seal of God in their foreheads, representing the protected faithful
The kings and rulers, representing earthly authority
The animals of the earth, representing creation’s sanctity
The inhabitants of Jerusalem, representing God's chosen city
questions.correctAnswer: Those who have the seal of God in their foreheads, representing the protected faithful
questions.explanation: Verse 4 specifies locusts must not hurt those sealed by God, indicating divine protection over the faithful, a motif consistent with sealing imagery elsewhere (e.g., Ezekiel 9).

questions.question: How long were the locusts permitted to torment men according to Revelation 9:5, and what is the significance of this time period in biblical prophecy?
options: Five months, symbolizing a limited period of divine judgment
One year, symbolizing a cycle of judgment
Forty days, symbolizing testing and trial
questions.correctAnswer: Five months, symbolizing a limited period of divine judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 5 mentions five months of torment, reflecting a finite period of punishment, which aligns with prophetic patterns of temporary affliction before restoration.

questions.question: What is the significance of men seeking death but not finding it in Revelation 9:6, and how does this relate to Old Testament themes of suffering?
options: It emphasizes unbearable torment and hopelessness, paralleling Job’s suffering
It illustrates the power of God to withhold death as mercy
It signifies a metaphorical death of the spirit
It indicates a temporary suspension of physical death
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes unbearable torment and hopelessness, paralleling Job’s suffering
questions.explanation: Verse 6 depicts a state of intense suffering where death is desired but unattainable, echoing themes of unrelenting pain found in Job and other wisdom literature.

questions.question: Describe the locusts’ appearance as given in Revelation 9:7-9 and explain how these images combine human, animal, and military motifs to convey their terrifying nature.
options: Horses prepared for battle, crowns like gold, faces of men, hair of women, teeth of lions, breastplates of iron, wings sounding like chariots
Serpents with heads of dragons, eyes of fire, and feet like bears
Giants with flaming swords, faces like the sun, and feet like pillars
Angelic beings with trumpets, robes of light, and flaming swords
questions.correctAnswer: Horses prepared for battle, crowns like gold, faces of men, hair of women, teeth of lions, breastplates of iron, wings sounding like chariots
questions.explanation: Verses 7-9 richly describe locusts mixing human (faces), animal (teeth of lions), and military (breastplates, wings sounding like chariots) imagery to portray a fearsome, judgmental army.

questions.question: The king of the locusts is called Abaddon in Hebrew and Apollyon in Greek (Revelation 9:11). What is the significance of these names in the context of biblical and cultural understanding?
options: Both names mean 'Destroyer,' linking the king to destructive power
Both names mean 'Messenger,' indicating a divine envoy
questions.correctAnswer: Both names mean 'Destroyer,' linking the king to destructive power
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states Abaddon and Apollyon mean 'Destroyer,' emphasizing the angel’s role as leader of destructive forces, consistent with apocalyptic imagery of cosmic judgment.

questions.question: What is the literary function of the phrase 'One woe is past; and, behold, there come two woes more hereafter' in Revelation 9:12?
options: It serves as a structural marker signaling escalating judgment
It signals the end of all woes
It introduces a message of hope and restoration
It functions as a summary of past events
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a structural marker signaling escalating judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 12 acts as a literary hinge, marking the completion of one judgment (one woe) and warning of two more to intensify the apocalyptic sequence.

questions.question: In Revelation 9:14-15, four angels bound at the Euphrates are released to kill a third of mankind. How does this relate to Old Testament narratives involving the Euphrates River?
options: The Euphrates often marks boundaries for divine judgment and invasion, as in Jeremiah and Ezekiel
The Euphrates is a symbol of life-giving water in Psalms
The Euphrates is depicted as a place of refuge for the righteous in Isaiah
The Euphrates is a metaphor for the resurrection in Daniel
questions.correctAnswer: The Euphrates often marks boundaries for divine judgment and invasion, as in Jeremiah and Ezekiel
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 evoke the Euphrates as a geopolitical and symbolic boundary from which judgmental forces emerge, paralleling prophetic texts like Jeremiah 46 and Ezekiel 30.

questions.question: What is the size of the army of horsemen in Revelation 9:16, and how does this number symbolically relate to biblical numerology?
options: Two hundred million, symbolizing overwhelming divine judgment
Twelve thousand, symbolizing the tribes of Israel
Ten thousand, symbolizing a large but manageable force
questions.correctAnswer: Two hundred million, symbolizing overwhelming divine judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states 200 million horsemen, a massive number symbolic of unstoppable judgment, far exceeding typical biblical military figures and underscoring apocalyptic scale.

questions.question: The horses in Revelation 9:17 have heads like lions and mouths issuing fire, smoke, and brimstone. Which Old Testament imagery does this recall and what does it symbolize?
options: The cherubim in Ezekiel’s vision, symbolizing divine wrath and power
The burning bush in Exodus, symbolizing God’s presence
The serpent in Genesis, symbolizing temptation
The manna in the wilderness, symbolizing provision
questions.correctAnswer: The cherubim in Ezekiel’s vision, symbolizing divine wrath and power
questions.explanation: Verse 17’s fiery, lion-headed horses reflect Ezekiel 1’s cherubim with multiple faces and fiery features, symbolizing God’s mighty and fearsome judgment.

questions.question: According to Revelation 9:20-21, what is the response of the survivors to the plagues, and how does this reflect a broader biblical theme?
options: They did not repent, continuing idolatry and sin, reflecting human stubbornness against God
They repented and turned to God, illustrating grace
They fled to the mountains, symbolizing refuge
They built altars to God, symbolizing worship
questions.correctAnswer: They did not repent, continuing idolatry and sin, reflecting human stubbornness against God
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 show survivors refusing repentance despite severe judgment, a recurring biblical theme of hardened hearts in the face of divine warning.

questions.question: True or False: The locusts in Revelation 9 are described as having tails with stings that have the power to kill men instantly.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:5 and 9:10 clarify the locusts have tails like scorpions with stings that torment men for five months but do not kill them.

questions.question: What does the Greek name 'Apollyon' mean, and how does its meaning complement the Hebrew name 'Abaddon' given to the king of the locusts in Revelation 9:11?
options: Destroyer, complementing Abaddon’s meaning as destruction and ruin
questions.correctAnswer: Destroyer, complementing Abaddon’s meaning as destruction and ruin
questions.explanation: Verse 11 explains Apollyon is Greek for 'Destroyer,' which parallels the Hebrew Abaddon, both signifying the king's destructive authority.

theological.title: Revelation Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Revelation Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Revelation 9, who is given the key to the bottomless pit?
options: The angel of the bottomless pit
questions.correctAnswer: The fifth angel
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:1 states that the fifth angel sounded and was given the key to the bottomless pit. This depicts God's sovereign delegation of authority to angels (cf. Luke 10:18, Revelation 1:18, Isaiah 14:15, Matthew 16:19).

questions.question: What effect does the smoke from the bottomless pit have on the sun and the air?
questions.correctAnswer: They are darkened
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:2 explains that the smoke darkened the sun and air, symbolizing divine judgment and spiritual obscurity (cf. Exodus 10:21-23, Joel 2:2, Ezekiel 32:7, Psalm 18:9).

questions.question: According to Revelation 9, what power are the locusts given?
options: The power of scorpions to sting and torment
The power to destroy all plants
questions.correctAnswer: The power of scorpions to sting and torment
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:3 states the locusts had power like scorpions to torment, not kill, reflecting God's controlled judgment (cf. Job 1:6-12, 2:7, Luke 10:19, Exodus 23:28).

questions.question: Who are the locusts commanded not to harm?
options: Those with the seal of God on their foreheads
questions.correctAnswer: Those with the seal of God on their foreheads
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:4 commands the locusts not to harm those bearing God's seal, indicating divine protection for the faithful (cf. Revelation 7:3, Ezekiel 9:4-6, Exodus 12:7, Psalm 91:7).

questions.question: How long is the torment inflicted by the locusts to last?
questions.correctAnswer: Five months
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:5 specifies the torment's duration as five months, symbolizing a limited period of divine judgment (cf. Exodus 10:4, Daniel 7:25, Revelation 12:6, Joel 2:1-11).

questions.question: What is the reaction of men during the locusts’ torment according to Revelation 9?
options: They seek death but cannot find it
They repent and turn to God
questions.correctAnswer: They seek death but cannot find it
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:6 reveals men desire death as relief but it flees, illustrating the severity of judgment and human despair (cf. Job 3:11, Ecclesiastes 4:2, Romans 7:24, Hebrews 2:15).

questions.question: How does Revelation 9 describe the appearance of the locusts?
options: Like horses prepared for battle with faces like men
questions.correctAnswer: Like horses prepared for battle with faces like men
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:7 describes locusts as horse-like warriors with human faces, symbolizing a terrifying judgment force (cf. Ezekiel 1:10, Joel 2:4-5, Zechariah 1:8, Revelation 6:4).

questions.question: What is the name of the king over the locusts, and what do his names mean?
options: Michael and Gabriel, meaning Warrior and Messenger
Satan and Lucifer, meaning Adversary and Light-bearer
Beelzebub and Belial, meaning Lord of Flies and Worthless
questions.correctAnswer: Abaddon (Hebrew) and Apollyon (Greek), meaning Destroyer
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:11 identifies the locust king as Abaddon/Apollyon, meaning destroyer, highlighting the destructive role of demonic powers (cf. Job 26:6, Proverbs 15:11, Psalm 88:12, Isaiah 14:12-15).

questions.question: What are the four angels loosed from the Euphrates river appointed to do?
options: To kill a third part of men
To bring peace to the earth
questions.correctAnswer: To kill a third part of men
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:15 states the four angels loosed from Euphrates are prepared to kill a third of mankind, symbolizing severe judgment (cf. Exodus 7:20, Joel 2:20, Revelation 6:8, Isaiah 66:15).

questions.question: How many horsemen are in the army described in Revelation 9?
questions.correctAnswer: Two hundred million
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:16 specifies 200 million horsemen, indicating an overwhelming force of judgment, emphasizing God's sovereign control (cf. 2 Chronicles 2:17, Jeremiah 51:27, Zechariah 14:3, Psalm 68:17).

questions.question: What are the characteristics of the horses and riders in the vision of Revelation 9?
options: Breastplates of fire, jacinth, brimstone; heads like lions; fire, smoke, brimstone from mouths
Clothed in white robes; crowns on their heads; trumpets in hand
Wearing chains; faces like angels; wings of eagles
Riding dragons; breathing fire; holding swords
questions.correctAnswer: Breastplates of fire, jacinth, brimstone; heads like lions; fire, smoke, brimstone from mouths
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:17 describes the horses and riders with fiery, lion-like, and brimstone elements symbolizing divine wrath and destructive power (cf. Ezekiel 1:13, Revelation 6:4, Nahum 1:6, Isaiah 30:27).

questions.question: By what means is the third part of men killed according to Revelation 9?
options: By fire, smoke, and brimstone from the horses’ mouths
questions.correctAnswer: By fire, smoke, and brimstone from the horses’ mouths
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:18 explains that fire, smoke, and brimstone from the horses’ mouths kill a third of men, illustrating God's direct judgment through supernatural means (cf. Revelation 20:9, Ezekiel 38:22, Psalm 11:6, Isaiah 66:15).

questions.question: What is the symbolic significance of the tails like serpents with heads on the horses in Revelation 9?
options: They are instruments of harm and deception
questions.correctAnswer: They are instruments of harm and deception
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:19 describes serpent-like tails with heads used to harm, symbolizing satanic evil and deception (cf. Genesis 3:1, John 8:44, 2 Corinthians 11:14, Isaiah 30:6).

questions.question: Despite the plagues in Revelation 9, what do the remaining men refuse to do?
options: Repent of worshipping devils and idols
questions.correctAnswer: Repent of worshipping devils and idols
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:20 shows unrepentant men continue idol worship and sin, highlighting human hardness of heart (cf. Romans 1:21-23, Exodus 20:3-5, Psalm 106:36-37, Jeremiah 2:11).

questions.question: Which sins are specifically mentioned as not being repented of in Revelation 9?
questions.correctAnswer: Murders, sorceries, fornication, and thefts
questions.explanation: Revelation 9:21 lists these sins as unrepented, indicating the depth of human rebellion against God (cf. Galatians 5:19-21, 1 John 3:15, Exodus 20:13-15, Acts 8:9-24).
